so first up to make tahini sauce you
need some tahini which is nothing more
than a ground sesame seed paste and if
we're being honest on its own it's not
the most delicious stuff in the world in
fact remember when you were a kid and
your mom brought home that sugar-free
peanut butter to try but didn't tell you
and you bit into your peanut butter
toast and you were like what the hell is
this that's kind of what this stuff
tastes like which is why it really needs
the ingredients you're going to see us
add here so we can turn it into
something significantly more appetizing
so what we'll do is we'll toss them in a
bowl to which we're going to add a
little bit of garlic and here's where I
totally screwed up this really only
needs like a clove of garlic but for
whatever reason I was in the mood for a
lot of garlic so I added extra way too
much extra it basically turned my tahini
sauce into a garlic sauce so the moral
to this very quick story is if you're
going to significantly increase the
amount of an ingredient in a recipe you
have to do it incrementally you don't
just dump in a massive extra amount and
hope it's right so that was a total
rookie mistake but anyway enough about
that for now I also added a little bit
of olive oil this is technically
optional a lot of people don't add it
but I do like the richness it adds and
also of course a little bit of flavor
we're also going to want a pinch of salt
to taste of course and then probably the
most important ingredient besides the
sesame seed paste a good amount of fresh
lemon juice so we'll pour that in and
we'll stir this up and what's going to
happen it's going to seem kind of loose
but as you stir it kind of seizes up
tightens up thickens up and you can end
up with something that looks like this
which is way too thick but that's fine
because the last step of tahini sauce is
slowly adding in some warm water a
little splash at a time until you have
the perfect texture and what's the
perfect texture you decide you are the
Houdini of your tahini and I don't mean
the magician I mean the group
when the road freaks come out at night
so that's totally going to be up to you
all right some people like a thick some
people like it super super thin almost
watery but anyway like I said we're
going to stir in splashes of warm water
until we have what we think is the
perfect consistency personally I shoot
for something similar to a thin salad
dressing at that point we're done except
for of course the obligatory taste and
adjust so you want to taste this for
salt acidity you may want more lemon
juice this is one of those recipes were
if it doesn't come out tasting like you
want it's totally your fault
which makes it just like what's that

every single recipe we've ever done and
by the way it was right about here when

this is like 20 percent raw garlic all
right you can always add but you can't

on purpose to teach you a lesson but I
didn't but anyway not that big of a deal
well it wasn't a great tahini sauce it
was a pretty good garlic sauce and at
this point it would be ready to serve
but I do suggest wrapping it up and
putting it away for a few hours that's
going to give the flavors time to
develop and also when you pull it out to
serve it you'll be able to taste it and
adjust it much more accurately alright
sometimes if we taste things too many
times while we're making it we get
palate fatigue and you just don't
accurately sense the different flavors
and seasonings but regardless whether
you let it rest or not once this is
tasting how we want it we can go ahead
and serve it up and I decided to garnish
mine with some sumac and chopped parsley
and in addition to being one of the few
purple spices sumac provides a kind of
tart lemony flavor which is very nice
and I probably should mention at this
point some varieties of sumac are
poisonous so you'll want to buy this
from a reputable spice dealer as opposed
to that tree in the backyard but anyway
a little sumac a little parsley and our
